metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: ECMAScript 2017
JavaScript Version Numbers
Old ECMAScript versions was named by numbers: ES5 and ES6.
content.html: Old ECMAScript versions was named by numbers: ES5 and ES6.

content.text: From 2016, versions are named by year: ES2016, 2018, 2020 ...
content.html: From 2016, versions are named by year: ES2016, 2018, 2020 ...

content.text: New Features in ECMAScript 2017
This chapter introduces the new features in ECMAScript 2017:
content.html: This chapter introduces the new features in ECMAScript 2017:

content.text: ES 2017 is fully supported in all modern browsers since September 2017:
content.html: ES 2017 is fully supported in all modern browsers since September 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 57 Edge 15 Firefox 48 Safari 11 Opera 44
Mar 2017 Apr 2017 Aug 2016 Sep 2017 Mar 2017

content.text: JavaScript String Padding
ECMAScript 2017 added two string methods to JavaScript: padStart() and padEnd() to support padding at the beginning and at the end of a string.
content.html: ECMAScript 2017 added two string methods to JavaScript: padStart() and padEnd() to support padding at the beginning and at the end of a string.

content.code_html:
let text = "5";
text = text.padStart(4,0);

content.text: JavaScript string padding is supported in all modern browsers since April 2017:
content.html: JavaScript string padding is supported in all modern browsers since April 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 57 Edge 15 Firefox 48 Safari 10 Opera 44
Mar 2017 Apr 2017 Aug 2016 Sep 2016 Mar 2017

content.text: JavaScript Object Entries
ECMAScript 2017 added the Object.entries() method to objects.
Object.entries() returns an array of the key/value pairs in an object:
content.html: Object.entries() returns an array of the key/value pairs in an object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName : "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  age : 50,
  eyeColor : "blue"
};

let text = Object.entries(person);

content.text: Object.entries() makes it simple to use objects in loops:
content.html: Object.entries() makes it simple to use objects in loops:

content.code_html:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

let text = "";
for (let [fruit, value] of Object.entries(fruits)) {
  text += fruit + ": " + value + "<br>";
}

content.text: Object.entries() also makes it simple to convert objects to maps:
content.html: Object.entries() also makes it simple to convert objects to maps:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.code:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

syntax_highlighting.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.code_html:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = {Bananas:300, Oranges:200, Apples:500};

const myMap = new Map(Object.entries(fruits));

content.text: Object.entries() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:
content.html: Object.entries() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 47 Edge 14 Firefox 47 Safari 10.1 Opera 41
Jun 2016 Aug 2016 Jun 2016 Mar 2017 Oct 2016

content.text: JavaScript Object Values
Object.values() is similar to Object.entries() , but returns a single dimension array of the object values:
content.html: Object.values() is similar to Object.entries(), but returns a single dimension array of the object values:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName : "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  age : 50,
  eyeColor : "blue"
};

let text = Object.values(person);

content.text: Object.values() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:
content.html: Object.values() is supported in all modern browsers since March 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 54 Edge 14 Firefox 47 Safari 10.1 Opera 41
Oct 2016 Aug 2016 Jun 2016 Mar 2017 Oct 2016

content.text: JavaScript Async Functions

content.code_html:
async function myDisplay() {
  let myPromise = new Promise(function(myResolve, myReject) {
    setTimeout(function() { myResolve("I love You !!"); }, 3000);
  });
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = await myPromise;
}

myDisplay();

content.text: Async functions are supported in all modern browsers since September 2017:
content.html: Async functions are supported in all modern browsers since September 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 55 Edge 15 Firefox 52 Safari 11 Opera 42
Dec 2016 Apr 2017 Mar 2017 Sep 2017 Dec 2016

content.text: JavaScript Trailing Commas
JavaScript allows trailing commas wherever a comma-separated list of values is accepted.
content.html: JavaScript allows trailing commas wherever a comma-separated list of values is accepted.

content.text: In Array and Object Literals, Function Calls, Parameters, Imports and Exports.
content.html: In Array and Object Literals, Function Calls, Parameters, Imports and Exports.

content.code_html:
function myFunc(x,,,) {};
const myArr = [1,2,3,4,,,];
const myObj = {fname: John, age:50,,,};

content.text: Trailing commas are supported in all modern browsers since May 2017:
content.html: Trailing commas are supported in all modern browsers since May 2017:

content.code_html:
Chrome 58 Edge 14 Firefox 52 Safari 10 Opera 45
Apr 2017 Aug 2016 Mar 2017 Sep 2016 May 2017
